description: The 6 p.m. meetings, all to be held in the Castine Center at Pelican Park, include:. June 9- April planning agenda;. Parish public information officer Amy Bouton said all attendees will be required to wear face masks or coverings and must submit to a temperature check before entering the meetings.
text:
The St. Tammany Parish Planning and Zoning commissions will meet in Mandeville
in June to consider three months worth of agendas.

The commissioners were unable to meet in April and May because of coronavirus
restrictions that prohibited most gatherings and required social distancing,
even in smaller groups.

Now that COVID-19 restrictions have been somewhat relaxed, the commissions
will meet in June. But the meetings will be relocated in order to comply with
the social distancing rules that are still in force.

The 6 p.m. meetings, all to be held in the Castine Center at Pelican Park,
include:

June 9 \- April planning agenda;

June 10 \- May and June planning agendas;

June 23 \- April zoning agenda; and

June 24 \- May and June zoning agendas.

Parish public information officer Amy Bouton said all attendees will be
required to wear face masks or coverings and must submit to a temperature
check before entering the meetings.

Bouton said the adjusted schedule was necessary to satisfy public notice
requirements and to accommodate the availability of commission members and the
Castine Center.

Using the Castine Center will also allow all parties to present their cases
and relevant materials while maintaining safe social distancing, she said.

The meetings normally take place in the Parish Council Chambers on Koop Drive
in Mandeville.

Covington attorney Jeff Schoen, who represents petitioners before both
commissions almost every month, said his clients have been frustrated by the
delays but understand they were necessary.

"They were dealt a set of circumstances that no one could have envisioned,"
Schoen said.

He called planning and zoning "the engine for a lot of the economy in St.
Tammany Parish." And, he said, "That engine is cool, and we need to know when
we're going to crank it up."

Bouton said the public should monitor local media, the St. Tammany Parish
website, [www.stpgov.org](http://www.stpgov.org), parish social media and
legal advertisements to stay informed on when and where all parish meetings
will take place and how St. Tammany is reopening.

title: Planning and Zoning's June meetings set, moved to Castine Center
html:
The St. Tammany Parish Planning and Zoning commissions will meet in Mandeville in June to consider three months worth of agendas.

The commissioners were unable to meet in April and May because of coronavirus restrictions that prohibited most gatherings and required social distancing, even in smaller groups.

Now that COVID-19 restrictions have been somewhat relaxed, the commissions will meet in June. But the meetings will be relocated in order to comply with the social distancing rules that are still in force.

The 6 p.m. meetings, all to be held in the Castine Center at Pelican Park, include:

June 9 - April planning agenda;

June 10 - May and June planning agendas;

June 23 - April zoning agenda; and

June 24 - May and June zoning agendas.

Parish public information officer Amy Bouton said all attendees will be required to wear face masks or coverings and must submit to a temperature check before entering the meetings.

Bouton said the adjusted schedule was necessary to satisfy public notice requirements and to accommodate the availability of commission members and the Castine Center.

Using the Castine Center will also allow all parties to present their cases and relevant materials while maintaining safe social distancing, she said.

The meetings normally take place in the Parish Council Chambers on Koop Drive in Mandeville.

Covington attorney Jeff Schoen, who represents petitioners before both commissions almost every month, said his clients have been frustrated by the delays but understand they were necessary.

"They were dealt a set of circumstances that no one could have envisioned," Schoen said.

He called planning and zoning "the engine for a lot of the economy in St. Tammany Parish." And, he said, "That engine is cool, and we need to know when we're going to crank it up."

Bouton said the public should monitor local media, the St. Tammany Parish website, www.stpgov.org, parish social media and legal advertisements to stay informed on when and where all parish meetings will take place and how St. Tammany is reopening.
